results.title: Capricorn charter
results.creator_credit: Movietone Productions, Queensland Government Tourist Bureau and Frank Killian
results.brief_description: Shows the tourist features of the central coast of Queensland, with scenes around Rockhampton, Heron, Great Keppel and Quoin Islands, Yeppoon, Emu Park, Gladstone, Emerald and the Mount Morgan Mines.

results.title: [St Kilda Junction Overpass]
results.brief_description: Construction first began in 1970. This film explores not just the site construction but ambient shots of the surrounding traffic, footage of the W-class trams that graced the area and marvellous aerial shots of St Kilda, Albert Park and the newly constructed Dandenong Highway. (NOTE: Worksheet in HOLD file)

results.title: Sunday in Melbourne
results.creator_credit: Melbourne Repertory Film Unit, State Film Centre of Victoria, Gil Brealey and Paul Olson
results.brief_description: An experiment in the creative use of colour visuals, natural sound and dialogue commentary, this film shows the loneliness of the aimless wanderers in the city streets contrasted with those who have companionship on their Sunday. (Award: Special Award for an Experimental Film in the Australian Film Awards, Melbourne Film Festival, 1958) Rights held by Gil Brealey.

results.title: Glenn's story
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School, Sue Dunstan and Arnold Zable
results.brief_description: A documentary based on a story written by a 15 year old boy in the maximum security section of Turana. Discusses his childhood and the events which eventually lead to his becoming a ward of the state and finding himself on the wrong side of the law.

results.title: A Bridge in music
results.creator_credit: Unesco, Alexander Shaw and Muir Mathieson
results.brief_description: Yehudi Menuhin and Eastern musician Ayana Deva Angadi compare Eastern and Western music and discuss how we can come to understand and appreciate that which is foreign to us in terms of that which is familiar. Characteristic techniques are shown, and the film includes examples of music from India, Japan, Cambodia, Italy, Germany and France.
results.description: Yehudi Menuhin and Eastern musician Ayana Deva Angadi compare Eastern and Western music and discuss how we can come to understand and appreciate that which is foreign to us in terms of that which is familiar. results.title: The Melbourne Concert Hall
results.creator_credit: Kestrel Films (Australia), The Victorian Arts Centre, David Morgan and David Greig
results.brief_description: Interviews with architects, administrators, interior designers, construction workers and others associated with the construction of the Melbourne Concert Hall. Artists who have performed at the venue also give their opinion of hall. Those interviewed include: Roy Ground, Neil Haysom, Theodore Schultz, Ken Myer, John Truscott and Kenny Christophers. Shows segments from performances by Jackie Love, Cleo Laine, Sylvio Gualdo, Karen Knowles, London Early Music Group, Mondo Rock, the guitarist John Williams, Brian May’s Melbourne Showband and conductors Piero Gamba, Patrick Thomas and John Hopkins. Views of Melbourne’s skyline capture the Gas and Fuel buildings that were demolished to accommodate Federation Square.

results.title: Hennessy's holiday
results.brief_description: The visit to Melbourne of Hennessy, a 180-pound St. Bernard dog. He sees the Botanical Gardens, the Sidney Myer Music Bowl, and the Shrine, and takes a run around the M.C.G. After intensive grooming he wins a prize at the Royal Melbourne Show, the takes a ride on the “Mightie Mouse” [sic], and he also enjoys a ride on Puffing Billy and a spin on the bay in a speedboat. A modelling appointment, having his portrait drawn by a cartoonist, and an appearance on ‘In Melbourne Tonight’ help make his visit a memorable one for all.

results.title: [Kirsty Sword Gusmao Film Collection: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
Titled Walking to School.
This could possibly be an Eaglehawk Primary School Production.

This narrative film follows the eventful journey of a young school boy as he walks to school along a country road. On the way he is joined by school friends and we see their encounters with a variety of native Australian Wildlife. They see lace monitor tracks and follow them to where the monitor is scaling a tree. They also find a possum and an echidna. The film shows various closeups of the animals and the children’s faces as they squint and shield their eyes from the sun.

The children cross a wooden bridge where they meet an old man carrying a swag and a billy. The man gathers the children around him and reads a story to them called “The Bear”. The film then shows us the story as it is being told. It is a tale of a young girl who is very poor, very dirty and very sad. One day she finds a toy koala which brings her great joy. Excitedly she tries to show her Koala to other school children who are playing games in the school yard. They ridicule her and throw sticks at her. She runs away and falls on the grass where she drifts off to sleep. She dreams that she is rescued by a fairy Godmother who transforms her into a very clean girl in a beautiful dress! During this sequence we see good examples of Super 8 “special effects” as the fairy works her magic on the other children, transforming them into characters in fancy dress. We see these children playing circle games and closeups of their faces. Eventually the poor girl wakes up to find a kind school boy standing over her. He helps her to her feet, takes her hand and leads her to join his other friends. Together the group skip happily all the way to school along a country road.

This film shows good examples of children’s fashion, games and faces. We also see footage of houses and streets of the time.

Selected Highlights (timecodes from Access Overscan)
00:00:06:00 Title card ‘Walking to School’
00:00:30:00 Goanna climbing tree
00:02:23:00 Echidna
00:03:45:00 Kids story time reading from ‘The Bear’

results.title: Northern oasis
results.creator_credit: Boort Progress Association and E.M. Jackson
results.brief_description:
A silent film about life in the North-Western Victorian country town of Boort during the 1940s. Produced by and for the people of Boort and district.
The Loddon Weir is shown, as are: local livestock sales, dairy, poultry, pork and citrus farming, school children at the small local school and Australia Day celebrations with athletics, a fashion parade, tennis, lawn bowls and decorative boat river regatta. The film ends with the “Water - the life-blood of the North. The future progress and prosperity of this Northern-Oasis depend upon its assured supply.”
